Synthesis and catalytic application of MOF-808 AA as heterogeneous catalyst in catalytic transfer hydrogenation reactions of α-Keto amides Anuprita A. Mathkar Writing – original draft Visualization Validation Methodology Investigation Formal analysis Data curation Conceptualization Bhalchandra M. Bhanage Writing – review & editing Supervision Resources Project administration Funding acquisition Data curation Conceptualization ⁎ Department of Chemistry, Institute of Chemical Technology, Mumbai 400019, India Department of Chemistry Institute of Chemical Technology Mumbai 400019 India Department of Chemistry, Institute of Chemical Technology, Mumbai 400019, India ⁎ Corresponding author. In this study, MOF-808 AA was synthesized by modulating the ratio of DMF to acetic acid, and its catalytic performance was evaluated in the transfer hydrogenation of α-keto amides using isopropanol (IPA) as a green hydrogen source and solvent. Furthermore, the methanol activation method was successfully applied to modify MOF-808 AA, resulting in a significantly enhanced catalyst that surpasses the performance of its pristine counterpart in the catalytic transfer hydrogenation (CTH) of α-keto amides. The catalytic conversion of α-keto amide to α‑hydroxy amide proceeded with remarkable efficiency, yielding 84–99 % conversion within a remarkably brief reaction period of 30 min. This protocol showcased remarkable catalytic versatility, efficiently converting a diverse range of α-keto amides, both activating and deactivating substituents on the aniline ring and benzene rings attached to the keto group. A comprehensive characterization of the material's physicochemical properties was conducted using a range of analytical techniques, including, PXRD, nitrogen adsorption-desorption, ammonia TPD, TGA, XPS, FTIR, SEM-EDX, CHN(O) analysis, and ICP-OES. These techniques thoroughly understood the material's structure, composition, and properties. M-MOF 808 AA demonstrated exceptional stability and reusability as a true heterogeneous catalyst, maintaining its activity without any discernible loss over at least four consecutive reaction cycles. A gram-scale conversion was successfully achieved to demonstrate the bulk scalability and industrial potential of the methanol-activated MOF-808 AA catalyst, highlighting its promise for large-scale synthesis and applications. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords MOF-808 CTH IPA Heterogeneous catalyst Data availability The data underlying this study are available in the published article and its Supporting Information. 1 Introduction The synthesis of α‑hydroxy amides and their derivatives has emerged as a pivotal concern in both industrial and academic contexts, necessitating the development of efficient methodologies that mitigate chemical waste, eliminate the use of hazardous raw materials, and simplify the overall process [1]. The synthesis of α‑hydroxy amides has been a focal point of extensive research, prompting the development of diverse methodologies and attracting considerable attention from the catalysis community. As biologically active molecules and intermediates, α‑hydroxy amides play a crucial role in the synthesis of DNA, proteins, complex heterocycles, and pharmaceuticals, including anti-HIV treatments and oxazolidinones, thereby underscoring their significance in modern medicinal chemistry and drug discovery [2]. Despite the availability of various synthetic methods, the preparation of α‑hydroxy amides remains a challenge. Traditional catalytic approaches, including enzyme and Lewis acid catalysis [3], often face operational simplicity, yield, and stereoselectivity limitations, necessitating the development of novel, efficient, and selective methodologies to overcome these hurdles. α-Hydroxy amides can be synthesized using α-Hydroxy acids, and diazotized α-amino acids. Acid treatment is a critical step in the synthesis, followed by a rigorous and gentle protocol to achieve the desired outcome [4]. As reported in the literature, the preparation of α‑hydroxy amides typically involves the selective reduction or hydrogenation of the α-keto amide functional group. To achieve this goal, numerous research groups are actively exploring various approaches. Traditionally, the chemoselective reduction of α-ketoamides to α‑hydroxy amides has been achieved through homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysis. However, homogeneous catalytic reduction methods have been more extensively reported and explored. Govindsamy et al. synthesized α-hydroxyamides using reducing agents like PMHS, with catalysts such as Ni(OAc)₂[5], K₂PdCl₄[6] or pH₃SiH/TBAF in THF [7]. However, the non-recyclable catalyst limited this approach. They also explored metal-free methods using PMHS with K₃PO₄ in 1,4-dioxane or Cs₂CO₃ in THF [8]. However, these protocols are marred by hazardous bases, environmentally harmful solvents, and non-recyclable catalysts, ultimately limiting their substrate scope and overall sustainability. Although Wu and coworkers have developed numerous synthetic methods for the chemoselective production of α‑hydroxy amides, recent breakthroughs have been made in metal-free reduction strategies. Notably, systems such as DMF/NaOH/H2O [9], HCOONa [10], and Hantzsch esters [11] have been employed. Despite this, higher-than-usual temperatures are needed to facilitate efficient synthesis and explore substrate versatility. Our research group has established an efficient and sustainable protocol for α‑hydroxy amide synthesis, leveraging UiO-66(Zr) as a robust, recyclable heterogeneous catalyst with isopropyl alcohol (IPA) as a mild hydrogen donor. However, this process is not without its limitations, namely moderate selectivity and prolonged reaction times [12]. The convergence of metal ions and porous architecture in MOFs unlocks novel catalytic opportunities. Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are hybrid materials composed of metal oxide clusters or secondary building units coordinated to organic ligands through strong coordination bonds [13]. This coordination-driven self-assembly process yields extended mono-, bi-, or tri-dimensional networks exhibiting crystalline topologies with uniformly distributed micropores and mesopores of molecular dimensions. A key benefit of these materials is their versatility, which can be achieved through modifications at the metal nodes, functionalization of organic linkers, and tuning coordination numbers [14]. This offers tremendous advantages in catalytic applications. Reducing the coordination number (from 12 to 8 or 6) creates open metal sites, facilitating the diffusion of bulkier substrates and enhancing catalytic reaction efficiency and this point is very much defended by Valekar and group [15] Various coordinated SBUs have been synthesized, which show good catalytic applications. But we are focused on 6 coordinated MOF-808. UiO-66 [16], Ru-UiO-66 [17], DUT-52 [18], IrNPs@ZIF-8 [19], and many more catalysts have been prepared and used for CTH of biomass-derived compounds as well as various functional groups such as Nitro and alkyne. The crystal structures of UiO-66 and MOF-808 typically exhibit non-idealities, which can be further engineered through the deliberate introduction of defects via coordination modulators during synthesis. Valekar et al. reported a groundbreaking finding that the porosity and metal nodes in Zr-MOFs significantly influence the catalytic transfer hydrogenation of biomass-derived carbonyl compounds [20]. Solvothermal synthesis represents the most prevalent and efficacious methodology for fabricating metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), owing to its versatility and capacity to modulate framework topology and composition. This enables the system to operate without needing specialist equipment and permits the relatively rapid growth of crystals with high crystallinity, phase purity, and surface area. Our group has successfully developed and applied UiO-66 as a catalyst for the reduction of α-keto amides, achieving product formation within 24 hours (Scheme 1 ). However, UiO-66 exhibits inherent limitations due to its structural composition. Considering the inherent limitations of UiO-66, we propose MOF-808 as a viable alternative catalyst for the chemoselective reduction of α-Keto amides. MOF-808′s structural framework, comprising Zr6O4(OH)4 clusters connected by 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate (BTC) linkers, offers enhanced accessibility and flexibility. This makes MOF-808 an attractive candidate for catalytic applications, potentially overcoming the constraints associated with UiO-66. Herein we propose the use of Zr-MOF materials as an efficient and active catalyst for the synthesis of α-Hydroxy amides via α-Keto amides, with IPA as solvent as well as hydrogen donor, that does not require additional base or external H2. Notably, our MOF-808 synthesis deviates from established protocols by employing acetic acid as a modulator, rather than formic acid. The resulting heterogeneous catalyst was comprehensively characterized using advanced techniques, and its synthesis involved a sequential approach combining acetic acid modulation with post-synthetic methanol treatment. 2 Experimental Protocol 2.1 Experimental materials Chemicals were acquired from established commercial sources and used directly, without additional purification, except where explicitly mentioned. ZrOCl2·8H2O, 1,3,5-benzene tricarboxylic acid (H3BTC) (≥99 %) was procured from zeta chemicals, Mumbai, and 2-propanol (99.8 %), N, N’-dimethylformamide (DMF) (99.9 %) was purchased from Oxford LAB Fine Chem.LLP. The α-ketoamides were synthesized from the corresponding acetophenone and aniline derivatives via an oxidative reaction employing selenium dioxide as the oxidizing agent. The reactions were carried out in acetonitrile as the solvent at an elevated temperature of 100 °C [12]. Pre-coated Merck silica gel 60 F254 plates (0.25 mm) were used for TLC, and UV/Vis. spectroscopy was used for analysis. SRL India provided 100–200 mesh silica gel for column chromatography. 2.2 Preparation of MOF-808 A modified synthesis protocol was employed to prepare MOF-808 based on recently published literature [21–23], with minor modifications to optimize reaction parameters. ZrOCl₂·8H₂O (0.5 mmol) served as the metal source in the synthesis of MOF-808. A 25 mL round-bottom flask (RBF) was charged with a mixture of acetic acid (2.8 mL) and N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF, 4 mL), to which ZrOCl₂·8H₂O (0.5 mmol) was then added. The resulting mixture was stirred at room temperature. After stirring the zirconium precursor solution for 15 min, a solution of 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (H₃BTC, 0.168 mmol) in 6 mL of N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) was added dropwise. (The Ratio of Acetic acid and DMF should be (1:3.5) with respect to acetic acid). The mixture was then stirred for an additional 10 min, followed by sonication for 20 min to ensure thorough mixing and homogeneity. Following transfer to a 100 mL Teflon-lined autoclave, the reaction mixture was subjected to solvothermal conditions at 120 °C for 24 hours. After the solvothermal reaction, the reactor was cooled to room temperature, and the MOFs were collected by filtration. The isolated MOFs were subsequently washed sequentially with twice the volume of DMF, acetone, and methanol respectively Subsequently drying at 80 °C for two hours and activation at 110 °C overnight yielded the final MOF material. 2.3 Synthesis of MOF-808 AA (Molar ratio 1:1) The synthesis of MOF-808 AA was achieved through a solvothermal process in a DMF/acetic acid solution in a 1:1 ratio. In the solvothermal reaction, A binary solvent system comprising acetic acid (30 mL) and N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF, 30 mL) was employed. Zirconium oxychloride octahydrate (ZrOCl₂·8H₂O, 0.49 g, 1.52 mmol) and 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (trimesic acid, 0.32 g, 1.52 mmol) were dissolved in the solvent mixture, and the resulting solution was transferred to a 100 mL Teflon-lined sealed reactor. (The Ratio of Acetic acid and DMF should be (1:1) concerning acetic acid). The reaction mixture underwent solvothermal treatment at 135 °C for 36 hours. After cooling to room temperature, the as-synthesized MOFs were isolated via filtration and subjected to sequential washing with twice DMF, twice acetone, and twice methanol. Subsequent drying at 80 °C for 2 hours and activation at 110 °C overnight yielded the final MOF material. 2.4 Methanol activation of MOF-808 AA The activation procedure for MOF-808 entailed refluxing 100 mg of the powdered material in 10 mL of anhydrous methanol within a 50 mL round-bottom flask (RBF) for 8 hours at the methanol boiling point. Following filtration, the powder underwent sequential washing with methanol (two times) at ambient temperature, and centrifugation at 10,000 rpm for 5 min to remove residual solvent. The activated MOF-808 was subsequently dried under reduced pressure at 80 °C for 12 hours. 2.5 Characterization Powder X-ray Diffraction (PXRD) analysis utilized Shimadzu XR-6100 instrument with Cu (Kα= 1.54 Å, 40 kV, 40 mA) scan rate of 2° /min and 0.02° steps in the range of 3°−70° using the 0.15 mm receiving slit. Fourier Transform Infrared Spectroscopy (FTIR) measurements were conducted utilizing a Hitachi STA 7300 spectrometer equipped with a diamond Attenuated Total Reflectance (ATR) accessory. This analytical technique facilitated the characterization of molecular vibrations, elucidating chemical transformations and functional group modifications within the membrane and Metal-Organic Framework (MOF) materials. Using a Carl Zeiss Supra 55 equipment (Germany), field-emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM) in conjunction with energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) was used to examine the catalyst's surface shape and elemental composition. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was conducted on an Omicron ESCA (Oxford Instruments, Germany) to investigate the surface electronic states, with internal calibration performed by setting the C 1 s binding energy to 284.6 eV. Inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES) analysis was carried out on an Agilent 5800 instrument. The elemental composition (C, H, N, O) of the samples (MOF) was determined by combustion elemental analysis using a Unicube analyzer. The catalyst's surface area was measured using a Microtrac Belsorp MiniX instrument, following degassing at 150 °C and N2 adsorption/desorption at −196 °C. Temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) of ammonia (NH3) was investigated using a Micromeritics Autochem-II 2920 apparatus to elucidate the surface acidity properties of MOF 808. A 500 MHz (¹H) and 126 MHz (¹³C) spectrometer was used to record the NMR spectra, and chemical shifts were reported in ppm in relation to TMS. 2.6 The catalytic behaviour and procedure General procedure for the CTH of α-keto amides The catalytic efficacy of MOF-808 was evaluated in the CTH of α-keto amides. A representative reaction involved combining α-keto amide (0.25 mmol) and M-MOF-808 AA (5 mg) in 2.5 mL of isopropanol within a 10 mL round-bottom flask, fitted with a magnetic stirring apparatus. For the purpose of completing the reaction, the resulting suspension was thermally treated for 30 min at 80 °C. The liquid was permitted to cool to room temperature following the conclusion of the reaction. After ten minutes at 5000 rpm, centrifugal separation was used to extract the M-MOF-808 AA catalyst. Next, water and ethyl acetate were used to wash the reaction mixture. The crude product that resulted from the collection and vacuo-evaporation of the organic layer was examined using GC–MS. Using a pet ether/ethyl acetate combination and silica gel, column chromatography was used to further purify the product. 3 Results and discussion Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) with 6-metal node connectivity and tunable porosity were synthesized using solvothermal methods. The successful synthesis of three materials, MOF-808, MOF-808 AA, and M-MOF-808 AA confirmed by all characterization Techniques. 3.1 Catalyst characterization As shown in (Fig. 1 ) Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) analysis was employed to investigate the structural properties of MOF-808, MOF-808 AA, and M-MOF 808 AA. Upon reviewing previous studies [24,25], the XRD patterns of MOF-808 exhibited two distinct diffraction angle peaks at 4.36° and 8.32° In contrast, the methanol-activated MOF-808 AA showed three prominent diffraction peaks at 4.36°, 8.34°, and 8.72°, corresponding to the (111), (311), and (322) crystal planes, respectively. Notably, the MOF-808 material was synthesized using an acetic acid to DMF ratio of 1:3.5. A subtle modification in the acetic acid to DMF ratio, yielding a 1:1 ratio for acetic acid, resulted in the formation of MOF-808 AA. Interestingly, this modification led to a noticeable change in the diffractogram of MOF-808 AA, where the primary peak broadened, indicating a potential alteration in the material's crystalline structure. These findings suggest that the AA method may yield smaller particles, improved morphology, and enhanced porosity, despite exhibiting lower crystallinity. This observation is corroborated by BET analysis (Table 1 ), which provides further evidence for the improved textural properties of MOF-808 AA. Application of the Debye-Scherrer equation revealed average crystallite sizes of approximately 9.0 nm, 13 nm, and 17 nm for Zr metal in MOF-808, MOF-808 AA, and methanol-activated MOF-808 AA, respectively. Notably, a significant peak broadening was observed in the PXRD pattern of MOF-808 AA, indicating the presence of mesoporous particles. Following methanol activation, the MOF undergoes purification, effectively removing small impurities. Concurrently, the treatment enhances the material's microporosity. Notably, the diffractogram of the methanol-activated MOF-808 AA reveals a significant decrease in crystallinity, indicating a more disordered structure. These findings demonstrate the successful incorporation of Zr metal into the MOF-808 framework, resulting in a nanoscale material with potential applications in CTH of α-keto amides. Notably, the structural integrity of the MOF was preserved, regardless of whether MOF-808 AA or methanol-activated MOF-808 AA was used. Both catalysts yielded slight amorphic structures, indicating that the activation process did not compromise the MOF's structural framework. Also, the activation step's role in enhancing porosity without destroying the framework is important. Following PXRD analysis, the catalytic activity of the synthesized materials was evaluated using α-keto amides as a model substrate. Initially, MOF-808 was employed as the catalyst, but it exhibited poor activity, yielding only a low product conversion (Table 3, Entry 3). In contrast, MOF-808 AA demonstrated superior catalytic performance in the transfer hydrogenation reaction of 2-oxo-N,2-diphenylacetamide, affording the desired product, 2‑hydroxy-N,2-diphenylacetamide, within 2 hours (Table 3, Entry 20). Subsequent investigations focused on the transfer hydrogenation capabilities of methanol-activated MOF-808 AA. Notably, a significant enhancement in catalytic activity was observed, with the desired product being obtained in remarkably high yield within 30 min (Table 3 entry 22). The identity of the product was unequivocally confirmed via GC–MS analysis. In the absence of a catalyst, the catalytic transfer hydrogenation (CTH) of α-keto amides failed to yield α‑hydroxy amides, even after 24 hours of reaction time at 80 °C (Table 3 entry 1). These findings offer significant insights into the potential of MOF-808 AA and methanol-activated MOF-808 AA as highly efficient catalysts for transfer hydrogenation reactions, as well as the underlying mechanisms responsible for their enhanced catalytic performance. Notably, the results unequivocally demonstrate that methanol-activated MOF-808 AA is the optimal catalyst for catalytic transfer hydrogenation, exhibiting superior activity and efficiency. Hence, a comprehensive characterization of MOF-808, MOF-808 AA and M-MOF 808 AA is essential to gain a deeper understanding of their physicochemical properties and their relationship with catalytic activity in this reaction. Both catalysts were thoroughly characterized using a range of techniques, TGA including BET, CHN(O) analysis, ammonia TPD analysis, SEM-EDX mapping, FTIR, XPS, and ICP-OES for loading purposes of Zr metal. The surface physicochemical properties of MOF-808, MOF-808 AA and methanol-activated MOF-808 AA were elucidated through N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm analysis (Fig. 2 ) and NH3-temperature programmed desorption (TPD) measurements (Fig. 3 ). These characterization techniques revealed the surface area and acid site distribution of both materials, including the presence of strong, moderate, and weak acid sites. The textural properties of MOF-808, MOF-808 AA, and methanol-activated MOF-808 AA were characterized using N₂ adsorption-desorption analysis. Notably, MOF-808 displayed a BET surface area of 700 m²/g, with a porosity of 1.1643 cm³/g and a pore size of 6.6561 nm, which is roughly half that of MOF-808 AA regarding surface area and pore volume. In contrast, MOF-808 AA demonstrated a significantly higher BET surface area of 1490 m²/g, along with a corresponding pore volume of 1.3162 cm³/g and a pore size of 3.4501 nm (Table 1). This discrepancy can be attributed to the differing amounts of acetic acid in the two materials. Specifically, the higher acetic acid content in MOF-808 AA allows it to function as a ligand, along with 1,3,5-BTC ligand, and coordinate with Zr4+, resulting in a more structured framework with improved surface area. This observation emphasizes the critical role of acetic acid in modulating the textural properties of MOF-808 AA. In contrast, methanol activation of MOF-808 AA led to a significant decrease in BET surface area to 377 m2/g, accompanied by a reduction in pore volume to 0.576 cm3/g and an increase in pore size to 6.1152 nm (Table 1). The observed decrease in surface area and pore volume for methanol-activated MOF-808 AA can be attributed to the detrimental effects of methanol treatment on the MOF framework. Methanol treatment of MOF-808 AA at its boiling point can lead to a reduction in surface area. This decrease is mainly attributed to the partial collapse of the framework or the removal of DMF solvent trapped within the MOF cage, along with precursor residues from the pores. [26,27]. This ligand removal effectively reduces steric hindrance and increases the pore size of M-MOF 808 AA by cleaving specific chemical bonds within the parent MOF-808 AA framework. The nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms (Fig. 2) conform to Type I behaviour, indicative of microporous materials, as per the IUPAC classification. A sharp increase in nitrogen uptake is observed at low relative pressures (P/P₀ < 0.1), confirming the presence of micropores. Moreover, the steep initial rise in the adsorption branch suggests the coexistence of mesopores, revealing a hierarchical pore structure comprising both micro- and mesopores [28]. Temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) of ammonia (NH₃) was utilized to elucidate the acidic properties of MOF-808, MOF-808 AA and M-MOF 808 AA. The NH₃-TPD profile (Fig. 3) provided valuable insights into the Lewis acid sites present within the materials. The area under the desorption peaks is theoretically proportional to the concentration of acid sites. To mitigate the impact of M-MOF 808 AA decomposition on the NH₃ desorption signal, the desorption temperature was carefully controlled between 80450 °C, thereby encompassing the characterization of weak, moderate, and strong acidic sites. The NH₃-TPD profile of M-MOF 808 AA revealed a distinct desorption peak, indicating the presence of acid sites with varying strengths. The primary peak, centred at 145 °C, corresponded to a moderate acidity of approximately 0.63 mmol/g. Notably, the acidity of the activated MOF-808 AA was further enhanced due to the removal of impurities from the MOF's cage-like structure, ultimately improving its overall catalytic performance. In comparison, MOF-808 displayed a weak ammonia adsorption peak, with an adsorption capacity of 0.61 mmol/g, while MOF-808 AA showed a slightly lower acidity of approximately 0.55 mmol/g. M-MOF 808 AA exhibited the highest ammonia adsorption capacity. NH₃-TPD analysis revealed a linear correlation between the desorption peaks, indicating a progressive increase in ammonia adsorption capacity. The enhanced ammonia adsorption capability of M-MOF 808 AA suggests a high density of accessible Zr sites. Consequently, the increased density of open metal sites, facilitated by these accessible Zr sites, ultimately leads to improved catalytic performance. Specifically, the zirconia active site plays a pivotal role in facilitating the chemoselective reduction of α-keto amides, wherein this synergistic interaction enhances the availability of α-keto amides for reduction and simultaneously activates the carbonyl carbon bond, thereby promoting an efficient and highly selective reduction process. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was conducted over a temperature range of 50–800 °C to assess the thermal stability of the adsorbent material, with the resulting thermogram depicted in (Fig. 4 ). The thermogravimetric analysis of MOF-808 revealed three distinct weight loss stages. The initial weight loss (I), 100 °C-250 °C was attributed to the desorption of volatile organic compounds, evaporation of moisture, and removal of residual DMF solvent. The subsequent weight loss (II), 200 °C-460 °C corresponded to the degradation of acetate moieties. The final stage (III), 460 °C-700 °C involved the decomposition of the benzene-1,3,5-tricarboxylic acid (BTC) linker, leaving behind ZrO2 as the residual material. In the case of MOF 808 AA there is a four steps weight loss process. The thermogravimetric profile exhibited three distinct weight loss stages. The initial weight loss (I'), occurring between 100 °C and 123 °C, was primarily attributed to the desorption of volatile compounds and the evaporation of moisture present within the sample. The subsequent weight losses (II' and III'), observed between 160 °C and 350 °C, were ascribed to the sequential removal of N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) and acetate moieties. (Eq. (1)). Following combustion (IV'), it is assumed that the remaining residue in the TGA experiments consists of ZrO2 (Eq. (2)) (1) [ Z r 6 O 4 ( O H ) 4 ( B T C ) 2 ( H 3 C C O O ) 6 ] ( D M F ) → [ Z r 6 O 4 ( O H ) 4 ( B T C ) 2 ] + ( H 3 C C O O ) 6 + ( D M F ) (2) [ Z r 6 O 4 ( O H ) 4 ( B T C ) 2 ] + 17.5 O 2 → 6 Z r O 2 ( S ) + 18 C O 2 + 7 H 2 O The methanol-activated MOF-808-AA catalyst exhibited a distinct two-stage weight loss profile, attributed to the removal of impurities. Thermogravimetric analysis revealed an initial weight loss (I'') between 100 °C and 159 °C, primarily due to the evaporation of moisture and residual DMF and acetate species. A subsequent, more pronounced weight loss was observed (II''), corresponding to the decomposition of the benzene-1,3,5-tricarboxylic acid (BTC) moiety. This two-step weight loss profile indicates that methanol activation effectively removes impurities, potentially enhancing the catalyst's performance and stability. In (table 2 ) the CHN(O) elementary analysis data is shown for the MOF-808, MOF-808 AA and M-MOF 808 AA. The carbon content in MOF-808 was found to be 23.11 %, significantly lower than the other two MOFs, likely attributable to the synthesis stoichiometry employed, which featured reduced amounts of acetic acid and DMF. The carbon content of pristine MOF 808 AA was determined to be 58.13 %, whereas methanol-activated MOF 808 AA showed a slightly lower carbon content of 56.09. However, CHN(O) analysis reveals that only a 2 % decrease in carbon content from M-MOF 808 AA occurred, suggesting that the DMF used during synthesis, which was likely trapped within the MOF framework cage, or carbon-rich impurities, were successfully removed during the methanol activation process. The percentage content of Zirconia metal was determined by ICP-OES analysis, which revealed a Zr concentration of 3.09 % The SEM image for MOF-808 shows that some degree of conglomeration with monodispersed morphology (Fig. 5 a-c). The MOF-808 AA exhibited low crystallinity, as evidenced by its XRD pattern (Fig. 1), and SEM imaging revealed spherical particles with uniform morphology (Fig. 5d-f) Furthermore, subsequent to methanol activation, SEM analysis (Fig. 5 g & h) revealed a predominantly spherical morphology of the particles, indicating a homogeneous distribution and effective incorporation. Notably, the presence of sieve-in-a-cage morphology and severe particle agglomeration suggests a well-ordered structure. Consistently, X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns exhibited a slight augmentation in amorphic character, corroborating the SEM observations and underscoring the efficacy of the methanol activation protocol. EDX analysis of the M-MOF 808 AA catalyst (Fig. 5i-k) confirmed the presence of Zr, C, and O components, indicating the retention of the Zr framework after methanol activation. ICP-OES analysis yielded a Zr content of 3.09 %, which corroborated the EDX findings and confirmed that the Zr framework remained intact after methanol activation, thereby validating the stability of the MOF structure. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was employed to investigate the valence state modifications of the constituent atoms in M-MOF 808 AA, providing insight into the electronic structure and surface composition. As shown in the XPS survey spectrum (Fig. 7 ), peaks corresponding to carbon, oxygen, and zirconium were detected, affirming the presence of these elements and confirming the successful synthesis of the target material, M-MOF 808 AA. High-resolution XPS analysis was conducted to elucidate the chemical state of Zr and C atoms in M-MOF 808 AA. The Zr 3d spectrum (Fig. 7b) displayed two distinct peaks at 181.9 eV and 184.3 eV, which are attributed to the Zr 3d5/2 and Zr 3d3/2 orbitals in Zr6O4(OH)4, respectively [29]. This finding confirms that zirconium is present in its expected oxidation state, consistent with the proposed material composition. Furthermore, the high-resolution C 1 s XPS spectrum (Fig. 7c) revealed peaks at 284.1 eV and 288.0 eV, which are assignable to the O C = O and C = C bonds in the benzene-1,3,5-tricarboxylate (BTC) ligands [29], respectively. The observed XPS peaks corroborate the successful incorporation of Zr6O4(OH)4 clusters and benzene-1,3,5-tricarboxylate (BTC) ligands within the M-MOF 808 AA framework, providing definitive evidence of its desired chemical composition and bonding architecture. The Fourier Transform Infrared (FTIR) spectroscopic analysis revealed significant structural modifications in MOF-808 upon incorporation of acetic acid as a modulator, providing valuable information on the resulting molecular interactions and bonding arrangements. Notably, the spectral features elucidate the interactions between the metal centres and the modulator molecules. The FTIR spectra of all three catalysts, as well as the recycled catalyst, are shown in (Fig. 8 ). The obtained results corroborate previous findings and provide a nuanced understanding of the structural and functional transformations imparted by acetic acid modulation, offering mechanistic elucidation of the resultant material property enhancements [30]. The infrared spectrum exhibits several characteristic peaks. The peak at 648 cm−1 is attributed to the Zr-O bond (carboxylate). The aromatic CH deformation and vibration are observed at 756 cm−1. The C = C stretching vibration of the aromatic skeleton is attributed to the band at 1441 cm−1. The FTIR spectrum exhibiting a band at 1560 cm−1, corresponding to the CC stretching vibration of the aromatic benzene ring. The carboxylate group (-COO-) is characterized by symmetric stretching vibrations at 1370 cm−1 and 1448 cm−1, and an antisymmetric stretching vibration at 1616 cm−1 [31]. Additionally, the infrared absorption bands between 950–1108 cm−1 (peaks at 950 cm−1, 1022 cm−1, and 1096 cm−1) are assigned to the deformation and vibration of the Zr-OH group on the Zr6 cluster [32]. The presence of peaks at 2928 cm−1 and 2842 cm−1, attributed to the sp3-CH stretch (medium) of acetic acid's (-CH3) carbon, in both MOF-808 AA and M-MOF-808 AA, suggests that increasing the acetic acid ratio introduces competition for bond formation between the Zr4+ center, 1,3,5-benzene tricarboxylate (BTC) ligand, and acetic acid modulator. This competition implies that acetic acid not only acts as a modulator but also participates in bond formation, contributing to the construction of the MOF's cage-like structure. This observation highlights the critical role of acetic acid in shaping the catalyst's architecture. The infrared (IR) spectra of MOF-808 and MOF-808 AA exhibit a distinctive peak at 1660 cm−1, corresponding to the stretching vibration of the (C = O) group. This feature is characteristic of the DMF solvent, indicating its presence as an impurity within the MOF 808 AA framework. Notably, this peak disappears in the IR spectrum of methanol-activated MOF-808 AA, suggesting that the DMF solvent is effectively removed during the methanol activation process, resulting in an activated MOF-808 AA structure. Following thorough characterization, the catalytic activity of M-MOF 808 AA was evaluated for the chemoselective reduction of 2-oxo-N,2-diphenylacetamide. To elucidate the catalytic transfer hydrogenation (CTH) mechanism, a systematic optimization of controlled parameters was conducted, encompassing the effects of catalyst selection, hydrogen source, temperature, and process duration. 2-oxo-N,2-diphenylacetamide was used as model substrate for optimization and model substrate for various composite MOF 808 as catalyst. 3.2 Catalytic activity of M-MOF 808 AA Initial screening demonstrated that the reaction was catalytically driven, as no product formation was observed in the absence of a catalyst, thereby underscoring the crucial role of catalysis in this protocol. (Table 3 entry 1) and then commercial ZrO2 (Table 3 entry 2) showed no product formation. After that the all three MOF were screened (Table 3 Entries 3–5) for CTH amongst these the methanol activated MOF 808 AA showed better result (Table 3 entry 22). A systematic investigation of hydrogen sources was conducted to elucidate the optimal conditions for the catalytic transfer hydrogenation (CTH) reaction. Among the various hydrogen donors screened, the formic acid:tri-ethyl amine (FA:TEA) mixture (5:2) showed moderate activity, affording a yield of 64 % of the desired product (2a) in toluene (Table 1, entry 6). Notably, a range of alternative reducing agents and conditions were found to be ineffective in facilitating the desired catalytic transfer hydrogenation (CTH) reaction. In particular, the combinations of NaCNBH3/MeOH and H2/MeOH at 80 °C under reflux conditions failed to promote the formation of the desired product (2a) (Table 3, entries 7,9), highlighting the specificity and selectivity of the optimized reaction conditions. Additionally, the reducing agent NaH was assessed in combination with methanol at room temperature. This is important because the reaction between NaH and methanol at higher temperatures is highly exothermic and can be hazardous. Unfortunately, even under mild conditions, this combination did not produce the desired product (2a) (Table 3, entry 8). Subsequently, we explored the utility of sodium formate and ammonium formate as reducing agents in the presence of methanol as the reaction solvent at 80 °C. However, despite optimizing the reaction conditions, including a reaction duration of 30 min, these reagents yielded only modest amounts of the desired product (2a), with conversions of 45 % and 40 %, respectively (Table 3, entries 10,11). These results collectively indicate that isopropanol (IPA) is a superior hydrogen source compared to FA:TEA for the M-MOF 808 AA catalysed CTH reaction, whereas NaCNBH3, and molecular H2 are ineffective in facilitating this transformation. To further enhance the yield of (2a), a systematic optimization of reaction parameters, including temperature and process duration, was conducted (Table 3, entries 12–22). The results indicated that a reaction temperature of 80 °C was optimal for maximizing the yield of the product (2a). Upon increasing the temperature to 100 °C, a decrease in yield was observed (Table 3, entry 12), attributed to the degradation of the product and premature decomposition of the hydrogen donor, isopropanol (IPA). Notably, the boiling point of IPA is 82 °C. At temperatures above this point, IPA begins to boil, rendering it unavailable for the reaction and thereby reducing the efficiency of H-transfer for reduction of keto substrate (1a). Conversely, lowering the temperature to 60 °C significantly reduced the reaction rate, resulting in a yield of 2a up to 78 %. These findings highlight the importance of temperature control in achieving optimal reaction outcomes. As for the duration, a systematic study of the reaction duration was conducted to determine its impact on the yield of (2a). A comparative study of the catalytic performance of MOF-808 AA and methanol-activated MOF-808 AA was conducted through catalytic transfer hydrogenation (CTH) of α-keto amide, with a focus on evaluating the required time duration for the reaction to occur. Notably, the results showed that the parent MOF-808 AA required 2 hours to achieve complete conversion of the desired product (2a) (Table 3 entry 19). In stark contrast, the methanol-activated MOF-808 AA (M-MOF 808 AA) exhibited significantly enhanced catalytic activity. Notably, when the reaction time was initially maintained at 2 hours, identical to that of MOF-808 AA, a yield of 99 % of (2a) was achieved (Table 3, entry 20). Subsequent reduction of the reaction time to 1 hour, and further to 30 min, did not compromise the yield of (2a), with complete conversion still attained within a remarkably short duration of just 30 min (Table 3, entries 21,22). Moreover, a remarkably low catalyst loading of only 5 mg of M-MOF 808 AA was sufficient to achieve complete conversion of the desired product (2a), highlighting the exceptional efficiency of this catalyst. Through a systematic optimization of various parameters, including temperature, solvent, and hydrogen donors, we have identified the ideal conditions for the chemoselective reduction of α-keto amides. Notably, our studies reveal that isopropanol (IPA) serves as both a suitable solvent and reducing agent, with optimal reactivity observed at 80 °C and a reaction duration of 30 min, utilizing M-MOF 808 AA as the catalyst. With the optimized reaction conditions established, we subsequently investigated the substrate scope of this transformation, exploring the chemoselective reduction of a diverse range of α-keto amide substrates. The scope of the catalytic transfer hydrogenation process was extensively explored by applying it to a diverse array of α-keto amides incorporating various activating groups and deactivating groups benzene ring attached to the keto group of the a-keto amides as well as to aniline ring affect the reactivity, demonstrating its excellent substrate tolerance. All reactions were performed under optimized conditions, and the resulting products were efficiently isolated by column chromatography using a hexane/ethyl acetate solvent system. Notably, the presence of deactivating groups resulted in good product yields, whereas activating groups led to comparatively lower yields. Specifically, the incorporation of electron-donating groups, such as -Me (2c), at the meta position, and deactivating groups, such as -F (2e), -Cl (2f), and -Br (2 g), at the para position, enhanced product yields. This phenomenon can be attributed to the decreased electron density at the carbonyl carbon. In contrast, activating groups like -Me(2b) or -OMe (2d) at the para position increased the electron density at the carbonyl carbon, resulting in decreased ketone hydrogenation to corresponding alcohols. Furthermore, the chemoselective reduction of heteroatomic systems yielded (2i) and (2j). The presence of a β-carbonyl naphthyl substituent (2 h) was found to be compatible with the reaction conditions, yielding the desired product with a high efficiency of 96 %. Furthermore, the methodology demonstrated adaptability towards heterocyclic modifications, as evidenced by the successful incorporation of furan (2i) and thiophene (2j) moieties, which afforded the corresponding products in satisfactory yields respectively, using M-MOF-808 AA, without affecting the reaction yield (Scheme 2 ). The catalytic system demonstrated broad substrate tolerance, efficiently converting α-ketoamides bearing electronically diverse substituents on the aniline ring, encompassing both electron-donating and electron-withdrawing groups, into selective α‑hydroxy amides under optimized reaction conditions. The sensitive functional groups such as -Me, halides and alkoxy moiety i.e. (–OCH3) (2l-2q) were untouched to give corresponding α hydroxy amides in good yields. Notably, a marginal decrease in yield was observed for fluorine-containing substrates, likely due to the ability of M-MOF 808 AA to abstract the fluorine atom, thereby affecting the reaction efficiency [28]. These examples highlight the importance of the current protocol for the chemoselective hydrogenation of α-ketoamides to α‑hydroxy amides. In addition to electron-rich functional groups. Fig. 9 Following the successful exploration of the substrate scope for α-keto amides, we proceeded to conduct control experiments to gain deeper insights into the reaction mechanism. Specifically, to assess the heterogeneity of the M-MOF 808 AA catalyst, a hot filtration test was performed. In this experiment, the catalyst was removed from the reaction mixture after just 5 min, and the reaction was allowed to proceed for an additional 20 min under identical conditions. The results showed that the catalyst was essential for the conversion of α-keto amides to α‑hydroxy amides, as no significant reaction occurred in its absence (Fig. 10 b) To assess the industrial viability of the methanol-activated MOF-808 AA catalyst, we performed a gram-scale conversion of α-keto amide to α‑hydroxy amide. Specifically, a 250 mL round-bottom flask (RBF) was charged with 10 mmol of α-keto amide, 200 mg of M-MOF 808 AA catalyst, and 100 mL of IPA, and the reaction mixture was heated to 80 °C for 45 mins (Fig. 9). 3.3 Recycle study Given the importance of catalyst recyclability in practical applications, we examined the reusability of M-MOF 808AA under the optimized reaction conditions. After each reaction, the catalyst was collected by centrifugation and washed with CH3OH, followed by drying at 75 °C for 8 h to prepare it for the subsequent cycle. After four recycling runs, a slight deactivation of the catalyst was observed, yet the product yield remained relatively unchanged (Fig. 10a), demonstrating that M-MOF 808 AA can be reused for at least four cycles with minimal loss of activity. Furthermore, the recovered M-MOF-808AA after the fourth recycle was thoroughly characterized by XRD, FTIR, SEM-EDX mapping, TGA and ICP-OES to assess its structural integrity and composition. Notably, the XRD pattern of recycled M-MOF-808 AA displays less intense and defined peaks compared to fresh M-MOF 808AA (Fig. 1), which may be ascribed to the substantial presence of residual guest molecules trapped within the pores of the M-MOF 808 AA catalyst. FTIR spectroscopy revealed minor changes in the spectra, indicating preservation of the framework structure. A weak absorption band between 3000–3550 cm−1 suggested the presence of slight moisture, likely trapped after the fourth cycle. Notably, the disappearance of bands at 2928 cm−1 and 2842 cm−1, previously observed in MOF-808 AA and M-MOF 808 AA, may be attributed to the removal or alteration of surface contaminants or impurities during reuse. This disappearance could also imply reversible structural changes in the material upon repeated use. (Recycled M-MOF 808 AA) [Fig. 8]. SEM analysis (Fig. 6) revealed that the spherical morphology of the particles remained largely intact after the 4th cycle, with only minor alterations and slight agglomeration observed, indicating minimal degradation of the catalyst's structure. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed on the recycled M-MOF 808 AA to assess its thermal stability and structural integrity after regeneration via the 4th cycle. The TGA curve exhibited a decomposition profile analogous to activated MOF-808 AA (Fig. 4), with minor deviations in the curve. TGA analysis revealed an initial weight loss (I'') between 100 °C and 159 °C, primarily due to the evaporation of moisture and residual DMF and acetate species The second stage (II''') took place between 400 °C-440 °C, indicating the presence of residual product impurities within the MOF framework. The third stage (III''') involved a steep decrease in weight, attributed to corresponding to the decomposition of the benzene-1,3,5-tricarboxylic acid (BTC) moiety. In conclusion, after the 4th cycle, subtle changes were observed in the catalyst, likely due to the presence of residual product impurities within the MOF framework. This observation is further supported by SEM analysis, which also indicates slight alterations in the catalyst's morphology EDX mapping confirmed that the Zr, C, and O content remained intact after the 4th cycle. ICP-OES analysis of the recycled catalyst showed a minimal loss of Zr, with a content of 1.79 % after the 4th cycle, indicating negligible leaching of the metal centre. However, a decrease in catalytic activity was observed, as evidenced by a 75 % yield of compound (2a), suggesting that some degree of deactivation occurred despite the structural integrity of the catalyst. The crystallinity, peak positions of functional groups, and pore structure of M-MOF 808 AA remained largely intact compared to the fresh catalyst, providing further evidence that the as-synthesized M-MOF 808 AA sample exhibits exceptional stability for the catalytic transformation of α-keto amides to alpha‑hydroxy amides. 3.4 Mechanism analysis Based on the experimental results presented above and previous literature [33], a plausible reaction mechanism for the catalytic transfer hydrogenation (CTH) of α-keto amides via open Zr metal sites is proposed (Scheme 3 ). In the first step, isopropanol (IPA) interacts with the Zr metal site, forming a metal alkoxide. This interaction facilitates the transfer of a hydride ion from the alkoxy carbon to the carbonyl carbon of the α-keto amide. The Zr (IV) centre, being in a high oxidation state, acts as a Lewis acid, coordinating with the carbonyl oxygen of the α-keto amide. This coordination enhances the electrophilicity of the carbonyl carbon, while the carbonyl oxygen exhibits nucleophilic character. Consequently, a six-membered transition state is formed, facilitating the hydride transfer reaction(B). Ultimately, protonation occurs through the action of another IPA (D) molecule, resulting in the formation of α‑hydroxy amide. Concomitantly, acetone is released (C), marking the completion of the catalytic cycle. 4 Conclusion In summary, this study demonstrates the excellent catalytic performance of MOF-808 AA in the catalytic transfer hydrogenation (CTH) of α-keto amide and its derivatives. Notably, the parent MOF-808 AA catalyst facilitates the efficient conversion of α-keto amides to their corresponding products within 2 hours. However, a remarkable enhancement in catalytic activity is achieved upon methanol activation of MOF 808 AA, enabling the completion of the reaction in a significantly shorter time of just 30 min. This striking improvement underscores the potential of methanol-activated MOF-808 AA as a highly efficient catalyst for this transformation. The recyclability and reusability of the catalyst were thoroughly investigated, and the results demonstrated its exceptional stability. The catalyst was successfully recycled and reused for four consecutive cycles without any significant loss of activity, underscoring its robustness and durability. The structural integrity of the catalyst was meticulously examined after four cycles using a combination of analytical techniques, including PXRD, FE-SEM and EDX mapping, and FTIR. These analyses conclusively confirmed that the catalyst maintained its structural stability, with no discernible changes in its crystalline structure, morphology, or chemical composition. Furthermore, a hot filtration test was conducted to verify the heterogeneous nature of the catalyst unequivocally. The test results clearly demonstrated that the catalytic activity originated exclusively from the solid catalyst, with ICP-OES analysis revealing minimal leaching of active species into the solution after four catalytic cycles. To underscore the robust scalability of the methanol-activated MOF-808 AA catalyst, a gram-scale conversion of α-keto amide to α‑hydroxy amide was successfully executed, demonstrating the catalyst's viability for large-scale industrial applications. This comprehensive set of experiments collectively demonstrates the outstanding recyclability, reusability, and structural stability of the catalyst, making it an attractive and sustainable option for industrial applications. coredata.dc:description: In this study, MOF-808 AA was synthesized by modulating the ratio of DMF to acetic acid, and its catalytic performance was evaluated in the transfer hydrogenation of α-keto amides using isopropanol (IPA) as a green hydrogen source and solvent. Furthermore, the methanol activation method was successfully applied to modify MOF-808 AA, resulting in a significantly enhanced catalyst that surpasses the performance of its pristine counterpart in the catalytic transfer hydrogenation (CTH) of α-keto amides. The catalytic conversion of α-keto amide to α‑hydroxy amide proceeded with remarkable efficiency, yielding 84–99 % conversion within a remarkably brief reaction period of 30 min. This protocol showcased remarkable catalytic versatility, efficiently converting a diverse range of α-keto amides, both activating and deactivating substituents on the aniline ring and benzene rings attached to the keto group. A comprehensive characterization of the material's physicochemical properties was conducted using a range of analytical techniques, including, PXRD, nitrogen adsorption-desorption, ammonia TPD, TGA, XPS, FTIR, SEM-EDX, CHN(O) analysis, and ICP-OES. These techniques thoroughly understood the material's structure, composition, and properties. M-MOF 808 AA demonstrated exceptional stability and reusability as a true heterogeneous catalyst, maintaining its activity without any discernible loss over at least four consecutive reaction cycles. A gram-scale conversion was successfully achieved to demonstrate the bulk scalability and industrial potential of the methanol-activated MOF-808 AA catalyst, highlighting its promise for large-scale synthesis and applications.
